newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks break record streak on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks break record streak on profit-taking.

text.p: Mexican stocks ended down for the first time in nine sessions Friday as dealers decided to take profits in a quiet session, traders said.
"The market saw profit-taking today, and sought to consolidate recent gains," said Hector Jimenez, an analyst at the Inverlat brokerage.
"This could be the beginning of the breather we've all been expecting. Today, however, investors were not bailing out, just selling moderately."
The blue-chip IPC index closed down 40.77 points, or 0.84 percent, at 4,821.62.
Trading volume was the lightest of the week at 87.7 million shares.

"Nothing much happened, it was just a normal retreat after the market shot through two resistances like they weren't there," a desk trader said. "We saw no earth-shaking economic or corporate news today."

Dealers said the most heavily traded decliners read like a roll call of stocks that led the recent rally, and was headed by Telefonos de Mexico (Telmex) and financial company Bancomer. Bancomer B shares fell 19 centavos (2.5 cents) to 4.19

Telmex shed 25 centavos (3 cents) to 21.00 pesos ($2.67). The telecommunications company's ADRs ended down 9/16 to 53-5/16 in a parallel move that shunned gains on the Dow Jones, which ended up 35.06 points at 7,921.82.

Vitro was one of the few blue chips that bucked the downward trend and gained 45 centavos (6 cents) to 35.20 pesos ($4.48) on what dealers said was a favourable reaction to second-quarter earnings it posted Thursday night.
On the broad market, decliners outnumbered gainers by 54 to 50, out of a total 115 stocks that changed hands.
